simplified_text:
The euro started in January 1999, but many people were unsure about it. On its first day, it was worth $1.19, but then it dropped to $0.83 in just two years. By mid-2000, the leaders of the G7 countries had to step in and spend a lot of money to keep it from failing.

At the same time, there was a short period of excitement about internet companies that began in September 1998. This was happening in a world where everything else seemed to be struggling. The old ways of doing business couldn't keep up with the changes from globalization. People felt that something had to succeed big time if the future was going to improve. The new internet economy seemed to be the only solution.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The euro faced skepticism and dropped in value after its launch in 1999, leading to intervention by G7 leaders. During this time, excitement over internet companies grew as traditional businesses struggled, highlighting the internet economy as a potential solution for the future.
